article.description:
Nick Collison scored 25 points and Keith
Langford added a career-high 24 as No. 2 Kansas romped past North
Carolina-Greensboro 105-66 Friday night in the second round of the
Preseason NIT.

images.name: McCants Rashad 021129 horiz top
images.caption: Rashad McCants and the young Tar Heels are now 5-0.

related.description: The Preseason NIT was anything but predictable, as UNC took the crown with a win over Stanford.
related.title: Kicking Up Their Heels
related.headline: Kicking Up Their Heels

article.headline: Collison, Langford power Jayhawks to rout

images.name: Simien Wayne 021122 vert top
images.caption: Wayne Simien will be the Jayhawks' focal point on offense as long as he remains pain free.

article.linkText: Kansas cruises into preseason NIT semifinals
article.story:
LAWRENCE, Kan. -- Keith Langford played up to his coach's
billing.

<photo1>

	   Langford made 10 of 11 shots Friday night as the second-ranked
Jayhawks breezed past North Carolina-Greensboro 105-66 in the
second round of the Preseason NIT.

	   Kansas coach Roy Williams predicted Langford would improve from
his freshman to sophomore year, and has he ever.

	   "I said at the end of the year Keith would improve his
shooting. I said at the start of this year that his shooting had
improved,'' Williams said.

	   In the first two games this year, Langford, the replacement for
the departed Jeff Boschee, is 17-of-19 from the field.

	   "He's still not Jeff Boschee,'' Williams said. "Let's not get
carried away. Keith played very, very well.''

	   Langford said he'd been working on his jumper.

	   "Coach said they might sag off a little bit because I didn't
show an outside jumper much in the first game,'' Langford said.
"I've been working on my shot. I put it up and it went in.
Everybody's confidence is real good right now.''

	   Wayne Simien had 18 points and 10 rebounds, giving him two
double-doubles in two starts.

	   Nick Collison scored 25 points and Kirk Hinrich added 23 for the
Jayhawks (2-0), who advanced to the semifinals in New York and will
play North Carolina, Williams' alma mater and the school that tried
to hire him two years ago.

	   After Williams agonized for a week and then turned the Tar Heels
down, the job went to Matt Doherty, a former assistant coach for
Williams at Kansas.

	   Williams, who improved to 14-0 all-time in the Preseason NIT,
admitted he would rather not play the Tar Heels.

	   "My entire life, I dreamed of playing there,'' said Williams, a
North Carolina native who was an assistant for Dean Smith. "I
dreamed of coaching there. I don't think anybody loves that
basketball program like I love it.''

	   Jay Joseph was practically a one-man show for the Spartans
(1-1), hitting his first nine shots and winding up with a
career-high 27 points.

	   "I don't think I have ever had a game where I was in that kind
of a groove like the first half,'' Joseph said. "The second half I
tried, but I just ran out of gas.''

	   Joseph hit one of his five 3-pointers and James Maye made a
bucket to slice Kansas' lead to 74-50 early in the second half.

	   But the Jayhawks then reeled off a 20-0 run that brought a
thunderous roar from the sellout crowd. Hinrich had two 3-pointers
in the run, which ended with 6:47 left and Kansas holding a 94-50
lead.

	   Joseph did not miss until a little over two minutes were left in
the first half. He also hit his first four 3-pointers and had 22
points at halftime.
	   
Joseph Maye had nine points for the Spartans.
